block.p: The Blackstone Group, one of the world's largest private equity firms, is getting ready to go public and its co-founders, Steve Schwarzman and Peter Peterson, are getting ready to cash in on the company they founded 22 years ago with $400,000.

Mr. Schwarzman, 60, will take home as much as $677.2 million, while his remaining 24 percent stake will be worth $7.5 billion if the deal is priced at $30, the middle of the range set by underwriters. (If it goes higher, he will be worth even more.)

The Blackstone Group, one of the world's largest private equity firms, is getting ready to go public and its co-founders, Steve Schwarzman and Peter Peterson, are getting ready to cash in on the company they founded 22 years ago with $400,000.

Mr. Schwarzman, 60, will take home as much as $677.2 million, while his remaining 24 percent stake will be worth $7.5 billion if the deal is priced at $30, the middle of the range set by underwriters. (If it goes higher, he will be worth even more.)
Mr. Peterson, 81, will get $1.9 billion, which he plans to put in a charitable trust, and will be left with 4 percent of the company.

Demand is expected to be high for shares in the deal, which could come to market in the next few weeks. But dark clouds are gathering for money-making machines like Blackstone. Two United States senators introduced legislation that could significantly increase taxes on publicly traded private equity firms and hedge funds.
